title: evoTS: analysis of evolutionary sequences of phenotypic change
text: evoTS package facilitates analysis evolutionary sequences phenotypic change. package extends modeling framework paleoTS package (Hunt 2006; 2008a; 2008b; Hunt et al. 2008; 2010; 2015) contains functions fit large range univariate multivariate evolutionary models implemented paleoTS. goal evoTS package offer larger range evolutionary models te study evolutionary changes within lineages. model-fitting procedures evoTS implemented mirror user experience paleoTS order make package easy use users experince paleoTS. example, univariate models implemented evoTS can fitted paleoTS object (.e. data format used paleoTS) fit univariate models paleoTSand evoTS directly comparable using reported AICc. evoTS also contain functions allow flexibility fitting combinations univariate models different parts time-series. Functions investigating likelihood surfaces fitted models also developed. evoTS also contains range multivariate models can fitted evolutionary sequences (time-series). models include different versions multivariate Unbiased Random Walks Ornsten-Uhlenbeck processes.

code: ## Creating dummy data  trait_means<-rnorm(20) trait_variance<-rep(0.5,20) sample_size<-rep(30,20) time_vector<-seq(1,20,1)  # Create paleoTS object indata.evoTS<-paleoTS::as.paleoTS(mm = trait_means, vv = trait_variance, nn = sample_size, tt = time_vector) ## Doing an approximate log-transformation of the data ln.diameter<-paleoTS::ln.paleoTS(diameter_S.yellowstonensis)  ## Convert the time vector to unit length ln.diameter$tt<-ln.diameter$tt/(max(ln.diameter$tt))  ## Plotting the data plot(ln.diameter.paleoTS)

title: evoTS: analysis of evolutionary sequences of phenotypic change
text: paleoTS package contains functions fit biased (GRW) unbiased random walks (URW), stasis (modeled white noise process, .e. uncorrelated variation around constant mean), strict stasis (real evolutionary change) Ornstein-Uhlenbeck (OU) processes assuming fixed optimum. paleoTS package also contains models punctuated mode evolution stasis mode evolution inbetween one two jump phenotype space (.e. punctuation). also possible fit certain models mode evolution shifts point evolutionary sequence. Several new univariate models implemented evoTS package. Functions also available fit mode shifts univariate models available evoTS paleoTS combined. also functions available evoTS allow one mode shift analyzed evolutionary sequence. following univariate models implemented evoTS package: Decerelated-evolution model (unbiased random walk exponential decrease rate change time) Accelerated-evolution model (unbiased random walk exponential increase rate change time) Bokma model (punctuated equilibrium model two (three) unbiased random walks separated one (two) jump(s) morphospace) Ornstein-Uhlenbeck process optimum changes according unbiased random walk.

what: 4.4 Ornstein-Uhlenbeck model with an optimum changing according to an unbiased random walk.
title: evoTS: analysis of evolutionary sequences of phenotypic change
text: paleoTS package includes Ornstein-Uhlenbeck (OU) model evolution single fixed optimum (Hunt et al. 2008). model portrays evolutionary adaptation trait towards fixed peak adaptive landscape. evoTS package contains OU model optimum (peak) fixed constantly changing according unbiased random walk. model proposed Hansen et al. (2008) analyses phylogenetic comparative data. Adjusted describe evolution single lineage, expected trait mean variance covariance given following expressions: \[E[z_{}] = e^{(-\alpha t_{})}z_{0} + [1-e^{-\alpha t_{}}]\theta\] \[Var[z_{}] =\left[ \frac{ \sigma^{2}_{step}+\sigma^{2}_{\theta}}{2\alpha} \right] \left[ 1-e^{(-2\alpha t_{})}\right] + \sigma^{2}_{\theta}t_{} \left[  1-2(1-e^{-\alpha t_{}}) \right]/\alpha t_{} + \epsilon _{} \] \[Cov[z_{},z_{j}] =\left[ \frac{ \sigma^{2}_{step}+\sigma^{2}_{\theta}}{2\alpha} \right] \left[ 1-e^{(-2\alpha t_{})}\right]e^{-\alpha t_{ij}} + \sigma^{2}_{\theta}t_{} \left[  1-\left[1+e^{-\alpha t_{ij}} \right] \left( 1-e^{-\alpha t_{}} \right) \right] /  \alpha t_{} + \epsilon _{} \] model can fitted using opt.joint.OUBM function. vstep.opt parameter represent rate change optimum. extremely small (virtually zero), means optimum essentially fixed. alpha OU model represents strength pull towards optimum. parameter easier interpret compared alpha half-life (log(2)/alpha), time takes trait move half-way optimum ancestral state. half life therefore quantification speed adaptation towards optimal state. decelerated accelerated models evolution, interpretation half life depends time-interval covered time-series. title: evoTS: analysis of evolutionary sequences of phenotypic change
text: multivariate Ornstein-Uhlenbeck process described following differential equation: \[dY = (\theta(t)-Y(t))dt + RdW(t)\] square matrix dimensions equal number investigated traits describes rate evolution toward optimal trait values (often called pull matrix), \(\theta\) vector containing optimum trait, R square matrix dimensions equal number investigated traits describing stochastic changes traits (R often called drift matrix) (Bartoszek et al. 2012; Reitan et al. 2012; Clavel et al. 2015). assumption one selective regime (optimum) per trait, expected trait mean Ornstein-Uhlenbeck process weighted sum optimum root value (Hansen 1997): \[E\left[Z_{}\right]= e^{(-At_{})}z_{0} + (1-e^{(-At_{})}\theta)\] \(Z_{}\) expected trait value sample , \(z_{0}\) ancestral trait mean, Θ optimum, pull matrix measures rate adaptation optimum, \(t_{}\) time interval ancestral population mean (start time-series, time 0) ith population mean. variance covariance sample means given following expression: \[Cov(z_{}, z_{j})=\left[P\left( \left[ \frac{1}{\lambda_{k} + \lambda_{l}} \left( 1-e^{-({\lambda_{k} + \lambda_{l})}t_{}}\right)\right]_{1\le kl \le m}   \odot P^{-1}\Sigma\Sigma^{T}(P^{-1})^{T}\right) P^{T}\right]e^{-^{T}t_{ij}}\] P orthogonal matrix eigenvectors , \(\Sigma\Sigma^{T}\) Cholesky decomposition R matrix, \(\lambda_{}\) eigenvalue ith trait, \(t_{}\) time interval ancestral population oldest two populations \(z_{}\) \(z_{j}\), \(t_{ij}\) time separating two samples z_i z_j, \(\odot\) represents Hadamard (element-wise) product. Different ways parameterize matrix allows testing range evolutionary hyptheses using multivariate OU process. R matrix multivariate version unbiased random walk (multivariate OU model) either needs diagonal (elements diagonal -diagonal elements zero) complete (sense diagonal -diagonal elements non-zero), case matrix. Generally, can divide hypotheses tested using multivariate OU four different types: Independent evolution (diagonal elements R matrix, .e. equivalent fitting univariate models trait separately.) Independent adaptation (diagonal elements matrix R matrix completely parameterized. model, traits adapting independently toward optima, stochastic changes trait correlated.) least one trait affects optimum trait. diagonal least one -diagonal elements matrix non-zero. trait column non-zero -diagonal element affects optimum trait row non-zero -diagonal element. stochastic changes trait can either correlated non-correlated. least two traits affect others optimum. Symmetric -diagonal elements present matrix. stochastic changes trait can either correlated non-correlated. dataset consisting two traits, four possible parameterization matrix (see panels ). Independent adaptation traits (panel ), trait Y affecting optimum trait X (panel b), trait X affects optimum trait Y, traits X affects others optimum (panel d). four ways parameterizing matrix can combined R matrix elements diagonal (stochastic changes traits uncorrelated) completely parameterized R matrix (stochastic changes traits correlated).  also possible implement model last trait data set evolve unbiased random walk affects optima traits data set. model can fitted defining .matrix =“OUBM”, sets last diagonal element matrix zero. zero diagonal element matrix means tendency trait evolve towards optimal value (case unbiased random walk. Setting .matrix =“OUBM” automaticall define R matrix diagonal elements (.e. option matrix override R matrix defined user). Multivariate Ornstein-Uhlenbeck models can fitted using two different funcions evoTS package. function fit.multivariate.OU allows user define parameterization R matrix using different arguments R matrices. .matrix can either defined “diag” (panel ), “upper.tri” (panel b ) “lower.tri” (panel c ), “full” (panel d ). Default “diag”. R.matrix can defined “diag” “symmetric”. function fit.multivariate.OU.user.defined lets user define elements R matrices parameterized. function therefore allows full flexibility type hypotheses tested parameterization constrained follow pre-defined options matrix available function fit.multivariate.OU. investigate whether two traits S. yellowstonensis lineage show evidence independent evolution (diagonal elements R matrices) whether adaptation part trait dynamics independent two traits (diagonal matrix symmetric R matrix). test hypotheses using fit.multivariate.OU function. model independent adaptation correlated stochastic changes much better independent evolution model. necessarily surprising know changes traits correlated investigation multivariate unbiased random walk models. half-life log diameter log number ribs 6.1% 4.9% length time-series, translates (13728 * 0.061 =) 837 (13728 * 0.049 =) 673 years respectively. correlation stochastic changes substantial, much reduced compared estimate correlation unbiased random walks. substantial part trait dynamics multivariate OU model due deterministic approach traits towards optima. model almost identical relative fit compared multivariate unbiased random walk according AICc, -competed unbiased random walk switch rate evolution. now test complex parameterization matrix gives us better relative fit. None models -diagonal elements matrix show better relative fit model diagonal symmetric R matrix. best model investigated remains multivariate unbiased random walk mode shift, allowing two different unbiased random walks explain trait dynamics. However, trust result, make sure run multivariate OU models different initial starting values, increase chances finding (potentially) different peak log-likelihood surface. number iterations can defined iterations argument. starting values drawn normal distribution standard deviation one. user can define larger smaller standard deviation using argument iter.sd. trace = TRUE allows user keep eye optimization proceeds. illustrate user can define elements R matrices parameterized using function fit.multivariate.OU.user.defined, can fit lower triangle matrix symmetric R matrix. lower triangle matrix means diameter affecting optimum number ribs.

title: Analyze Evolutionary Sequences (Time-Series) of Phenotypic Change
text: evoTS package facilitates univariate multivariate analysis evolutionary sequences phenotypic change. goal evoTS package offer large range evolutionary models enable detailed studies evolutionary changes within lineages. evoTS package extends modeling framework available  paleoTS package. model-fitting procedures evoTS implemented mirror user experience paleoTS. example, univariate models implemented evoTS can fitted paleoTS object, .e. data format used paleoTS. fit univariate models available paleoTS evoTS directly comparable using reported AICc. evoTS contains functions allow fitting different models separate parts evolutionary sequence. Functions investigating likelihood surfaces fitted models also included. evoTS contains range multivariate models, including different versions multivariate unbiased random walks Ornsten-Uhlenbeck processes. Together, models allow user test various hypotheses adaptation using phenotypic time-series.

text: Phenotypic data (diameter) centric diatom lineage Stephanodiscus yellowstonensis. time series spans 14 000 years. data set contains data valve diameter (measured micrometres). data consists object class paleoTS (diameter_S.yellowstonensis). Objects class paleoTS can analyzed evoTS. object (trait data set) contains vector sample means (mm), sample variances (vv), sample sizes (nn) sample ages (tt). oldest sample listed first. data spans interval 13728 years.

title: Fit predefined multivariate Ornstein-Uhlenbeck models to multivariate evolutionary sequence (time-series) data. — fit.multivariate.OU
text: yy multivariate evoTS object. .matrix pull matrix. options "diag", "upper.tri", "lower.tri", "full". Default "diag". See details (vignette) info different options mean. R.matrix drift matrix. options "diag" "symmetric". method optimization method, passed function optim. Default "Nelder-Mead". hess logical, indicating whether calculate standard errors Hessian matrix. trace logical, indicating whether information progress optimization printed. iterations number times optimization method run different starting points. Default NULL, meaning optimization run . iter.sd defines standard deviation Gaussian distribution starting values optimization routine run. Default 1.

title: Fit predefined multivariate Ornstein-Uhlenbeck models to multivariate evolutionary sequence (time-series) data. — fit.multivariate.OU
text: First part output reports log-likelihood model AICc score. second part output maximum log-likelihood model parameters (ancestral.values, optima, , R). half-life also provided,  last part output gives information number parameters model (K), number samples data (n) number times optimization routine run (iter).

title: Fit predefined multivariate Ornstein-Uhlenbeck models to multivariate evolutionary sequence (time-series) data. — fit.multivariate.OU
text: detailed explanation predefined models can fitted using function given vignette, short summary provided . Note function provides user fixed options parameterize R matrices. full flexibility, user allowed customize parameterization R matrix 'fit.multivariate.OU.user.defined' function. type trait dynamics defined based pull matrix () drift matrix (R) defined. function allows testing four broad categories models: 1 Independent evolution (.matrix ="diag", R.matrix = "diag"); 2 Independent adaptation (.matrix ="diag", R.matrix = "symmetric"); 3 Non-independent adaptation (.matrix = "upper.tri"/"lower.tri"/full", R.matrix = "diagonal"); 4 Non-independent evolution (.matrix = "upper.tri"/"lower.tri"/"full", R.matrix = "symmetric"). Setting .matrix "diagonal" means traits affect others optimum (matrix). "diagonal" R matrix means stochastic changes traits assumed uncorrelated. "symmetric" R matrix means stochastic changes traits assumed correlated, .e. non-independent. "full" parameterization estimates effect trait optima traits. "upper.tri" option parameterize model way first layer (first trait data set) adapts non-independently optimum affected traits included data set, bottom layer (last trait data set) adapts independently (Ornstein Uhlenbeck process). Layers upper- lower layer (first last trait data set (two traits data set)) evolve non-independently optimum affected layers/traits . option "lower.tri" defines causality oposite way compared "upper.tri". also possible implement model bottom layer (last trait data set) evolve Unbiased random walk (akin Brownian motion) affects optima traits data set (.e. layers except bottom layer). model can fitted defining .matrix ="OUBM", override R matrix defined. function searches - using optimization routine - maximum-likelihood solution chosen multivariate Ornstein-Uhlenbeck model. argument 'method' passed 'optim' function included convenience users better control optimization routine. Note default method (Nelder-Mead) seems work evolutionary sequences. method L-BFGS-B allows box-constraints parameters (e.g. non-negative variance parameters) faster Nelder-Mead, less stable default method (Nelder-Mead). Initial estimates start optimization come maximum-likelihood estimates univariate Ornstein-Uhlenbeck model (paleoTS package) fitted time-series separately. good practice repeat numerical optimization procedure different starting points. especially important complex models log-likelihood surface might contain one peak. number iterations controlled argument 'iterations'. function report model parameters iteration highest log-likelihood.

title: Fit predefined multivariate Ornstein-Uhlenbeck models to multivariate evolutionary sequence (time-series) data. — fit.multivariate.OU
text: models implemented compatible joint parameterization routine package paleoTS. optimization therefore fit using actual sample values, autocorrelation among samples accounted log-likelihood function. joint distribution sample means multivariate normal, means variance-covariances determined evolutionary parameters sampling errors.

text: First part output reports log-likelihood model AICc score. second part output maximum log-likelihood model parameters (ancestral.values, optima, , R). half-life also provided,  last part output gives information number parameters model (K), number samples data (n) number times optimization routine run (iter).

title: Fit user-defined multivariate Ornstein-Uhlenbeck models to multivariate evolutionary sequence (time-series) data. — fit.multivariate.OU.user.defined
text: function provides users flexibility define R matrices. possibility define matrices enable detailed investigation specific evolutionary hypotheses. parameters estimated matrices indicated value 1. entries matrix must 0. function searches - using optimization routine - maximum-likelihood solution chosen multivariate Ornstein-Uhlenbeck model. argument 'method' passed 'optim' function included convenience users better control optimization routine. Note default method (Nelder-Mead) seems work evolutionary sequences. method L-BFGS-B allows box-constraints parameters (e.g. non-negative variance parameters) faster Nelder-Mead, less stable default method (Nelder-Mead). Initial estimates start optimization come maximum-likelihood estimates univariate Ornstein-Uhlenbeck model (paleoTS package) fitted time-series separately. good practice repeat numerical optimization procedure different starting points. especially important complex models log-likelihood surface might contain one peak. number iterations controlled argument 'iterations'. function report model parameters iteration highest log-likelihood.

title: Fit user-defined multivariate Ornstein-Uhlenbeck models to multivariate evolutionary sequence (time-series) data. — fit.multivariate.OU.user.defined
text: models implemented compatible joint parameterization routine package paleoTS. optimization therefore fit using actual sample values, autocorrelation among samples accounted log-likelihood function. joint distribution sample means multivariate normal, means variance-covariances determined evolutionary parameters sampling errors.

title: Fit multivariate Unbiased Random Walk models to multivariate evolutionary sequence (time-series) data. — fit.multivariate.URW
text: function allows users test six variants multivariate Unbiased Random Walk models. two options structure R matrix. "diagonal" R matrix means stochastic changes traits assumed uncorrelated. "symmetric" R matrix means stochastic changes traits assumed correlated, .e. non-independent. three options 'r' parameter. "fixed" option means change rate change across time (r = 0). Setting r "fixed" therefore fits regular multivariate Unbiased Random Walk. "decel" "accel" options make rate change (R matrix) decay (r < 0) increase (r > 0) exponentially time, respectively. function searches - using optimization routine - maximum-likelihood solution chosen multivariate Unbiased Random Walk model. argument 'method' passed 'optim' function included convenience users better control optimization routine. default method (L-BFGS-B) seems work evolutionary sequences. Initial estimates start optimization come maximum-likelihood estimates univariate Unbiased Random Walk model (paleoTS package) fitted time-series separately. good practice repeat numerical optimization procedure different starting points. especially important complex models log-likelihood surface might contain one peak. number iterations controlled argument 'iterations'. function report model parameters iteration highest log-likelihood.

title: Fit multivariate Unbiased Random Walk models to multivariate evolutionary sequence (time-series) data. — fit.multivariate.URW
text: models implemented compatible joint parameterization routine package paleoTS. optimization therefore fit using actual sample values, autocorrelation among samples accounted log-likelihood function. joint distribution sample means multivariate normal, means variance-covariances determined evolutionary parameters sampling errors.
